entry.title: ä¸Halena
entry.content:
BOOKS

If you want to do easy

  • Junie B. Jones series by Barbara Park
  • Magic Finger by Roald Dahl

If you want medium/bit hard

  • Goosebump series by R.L Stine
  • Stargirl by Jerry Spinelli

If want hard

  • Dragonwings by Laurence Yep
  • Fault in our Stars by John Green
  • The Outsiders by S.E Hilton
  • The Alchemist by Paulo Coelho
  • To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee

Some of the books i read are:

  • Book Thief by Markus Zusak
  • Norwegian Wood by Haruki Murakami
  • The Count of Monte Cristo by Alexandre Dumas

FILMS

  • Cary Grant
  • Doris Day
  • John Wayne
  • Judy Garland
  • Mr. Blandings Builds his Dream House
  • Charade
  • The long long Trailer
iniOh cool! Okay, so the books that you are reading are different reading levels. If want to do easy, i suggest Junie B. Jones series by Barbara Park, Magic Finger by Roald Dahl. If want medium/bit hard, u can try Goosebump series by R.L Stine and Stargirl by Jerry Spinelli. If want hard, i suggest Dragonwings by Laurence Yep, Fault in our Stars by John Green, The Outsiders by S.E Hilton, The Alchemist by Paulo Coelho, and To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee

Some of the books i read are:
~Book Thief by Markus Zusak
~Norwegian Wood by Haruki Murakami
~The Count of Monte Cristo by Alexandre Dumas

Marilyn Monroe? Her movies are okay but my favorite actors in classic movies are Cary Grant, Doris Day, John Wayne, Judy Garland and more. (I was raised watching classic movies from my parents)

Ikr, when i was younger, my favorite movies from Cary Grant were:
~Mr. Blandings Builds his Dream House
~Charade

I dont know, i like other actors also. My most favorite comedy movie that is a classical movie is called â€˜ The long long Trailerâ€™ğŸ˜

entry.title: ESLPODç¬”è®°
entry.content:
A day in life of Jeff

getting up

  • covers
  • comforter
  • light blanket
  • pillowcase
  • sheets
  • jarringnuzzer
  • early riser
  • oversleep
  • sleep in
ç‚¹æˆ‘å¯å¾—åŸæ–‡

The worst part of the day for me is definitely when I have to get up. Waking up,
that I can handle. But getting up? That, I hate. The covers I have on my bed
are heavy, mostly because I have a comforter as well as a light blanket. I sleep
with two pillows, which for some reason have different color pillowcases. Well, at
least the sheets match.

I sometimes wake up before the alarm goes off. I like to keep the alarm at a low
volume, with some classical music, nothing too jarring. My old roommate used to
like the terrible buzzer that you find on most alarm clocks nowadays, which
always used to drive me nuts. As I was saying, I sometimes wake up before the
alarm, usually because of some noise outside the houseâ€”a car door slamming,
an alarm going off, gunfireâ€”well, okay, not gunfire, but man, is my neighborhood
noisy! Of course, when Iâ€™m staying in a hotel, itâ€™s usually easier to just get a
wake up call from the hotel than set the alarm.

Iâ€™m not really an early riser, so I donâ€™t jump out of bed ready to take on the world.
I get up very slowly, usually one foot on the floor at a time. Every once in awhile
Iâ€™ll oversleep, but not too often. I really love the weekends, when I can sleep in.

entry.content:
APWâ€“English pronunciation workshop training, you can watch full teaching videos by clicking there. Equipped handbook is here, with the passwordtrxx

1.R&W

R

â€˜Râ€™ at the beginning of words

Rock
Rip
Reach
Road
Rain
Rich
Rome
Raise
Robe
Rice

â€˜Râ€™ at the end of words or after a vowel

Car
Far
Star
Door
Bear
Four
Air
Year
Turn
Poor

â€˜Râ€™ in the middle of words

Very
Direction
Arrange
Erase
Correct
Marry
Garage
Original
Hurry
Zero
Marine
Berry
Operation
Caring
Arrive
Everyone

â€˜Râ€™ Sentence

The round rooster rushed into the wrong road.

â€˜Râ€™ blends at the beginning of words

Training
Trust
Trip
Great
Tropical
Bring
Print
President
Product
Cracker
Crawl
Break

â€˜Râ€™ blends in the middle of words

Subtract
Waitress

Introduce

Betray

â€˜Râ€™ practice sentences

  • The story he read on the radio was incorrect.
    -Her career in the law firm is permanent.
    -Richard and Brooke took a ride in their brand new Range Rover truck.
    -Everyone will respect the Royal Family when they arrive at the airport.
    -The trip to the Rocky Mountains will be rescheduled on Friday.

W

â€˜Wâ€™ at the beginning of words

Why
Which
When
What
Wipe
Wish
Weight
Wing

â€˜Wâ€™ in the middle of words

Always
Away
Beware

Awake
Someone
Halloween
Hollywood

â€˜Wâ€™ practice sentences

-The wind from the west was very wet.(Notice very has a /v/ sound)
-We woke up and washed the white washcloth.
-We waited for the waitress to give us water.
-We had a wonderful time in Washington and Wisconsin.

Q

â€˜Qâ€™ words (produced as a KW sound)

Question
Quiet
Queen
Qualify
Quit
Quebec

Choir

Word Review -

Ray
Russia
Dreamed
Roller Coaster
Grand Canyon
Arizona
Friend

Creative

2.Voicing&S

Paired Consonant

/p/&/b/
/T/&/D/
/F/&/V/
/S/&/Z/

Three rules for S/Z endings
If a word ends in a sound that is unvoiced (such as P,T,K,F), you add an unvoiced /S/ cups cats
If a word ends in any of these sounds: â€˜s,z,sh,ch,or dg (j)â€™when adding an â€˜Sâ€™ ending, addâ€¦ IZZZZZZ pages buses raises brushes pushes
If a word ends in a vowel sound (like the word Tree) or a voiced consonant (like the word Game), then when you add an â€˜Sâ€™, continue the voicing throughout the entire word, and it should become a voiced ZZZZ.trees days shoes flies heads

S

IS
HIS
AS
WAS
THESE
THOSE
EASY
BECAUSE
Another zippy, zappy, crazy day comes to a close. As we zoom up to Joeâ€™s snooze zone, Zoe Jones of Zodiac Zoo plays with her zipper.
Last week, Jimâ€™s brothers were picked to represent their country in the Olympic Games. Two of the brothers were swimmers, while the other two were long distance runners. All of the brothers wore glasses. These athletes worked hard at qualifying for the games and were hoping to come home with prizes. Since the brothers go to the same university, they often take the same courses. This makes studying easier and gives them more time to do other things.
On Thursday, I had a very lazy day. I woke up early and first squeezed oranges into juice. I then got dressed and watched the sunrise come up over the mountains. It was so beautiful that I took many pictures with my camera and I used three rolls of film. After drinking two cups of coffee, I got dressed, left the house, and walked three miles home.

3.TH

Examples

At begining

thanks
thick
thunder
thursday
think

In the middle

anything
bathmat
toothpick
athletic

At end

bath
north
beneath
fouth
south

The â€˜Voiced THâ€™ Sound

Voiced â€˜THâ€™ at the beginning of words

The (The book)
That (That house)
They (They came over)
Them (Give them water)
There (There it is)
This (This is my nose)
Those (Those boys are good)
These (These are my parents)

Voiced â€˜THâ€™ in the middle of words

Clothing
Leather
Mother
Another
Weather
Northern

Voiced â€˜THâ€™ at the end of words

Smooth
Bathe(bath is unvoiced)
Breathe(breath is unvoiced)

Pratice

Practice Phrases

This and that
A tablecloth
Winter clothing
Athens, Greece
Thatâ€™s the one
Her skin is smooth
Thirty Dayâ€™s notice
A famous author
Here and there
False teeth
Thread the needle
A thoughtful gift
Thunder and lightening
Thumbs up

Practice Sentences

-Thelma arrived in town last Thursday.
-Iâ€™m having trouble threading this needle.
-I need 33 thick thermometers.
-The thing they like best about Athens is the weather.
-This thrilling novel was written by a famous author.
-He will be through with his work at three-thirty.
-Now and then, she likes to buy new clothing.
-They thought they were going to Northern Spain.
-Which tablecloth shall we use for the party?
-That was the thirty-third theatre to open.

THR Blends

Thread â€œthread the needleâ€
Throw â€œthrow the ballâ€
Throat â€œmy throat is soreâ€
Thrill â€œa thrilling rideâ€
Three â€œthree more daysâ€
Threw â€œhe threw the ballâ€
Throne â€œthe king sits on a throneâ€

Paragraph Practice

Nurse Thatcher was thankful it was Thursday. She knew that on Thursday she had to deliver 33 boxes of thermometers to the North American Athletic Club. They thought that thermometers were necessary for testing the hydrotherapy baths. This was thought to benefit the athletes with arthritis. The athletic trainers required authorization to provide hydrotherapy to the youthful athletes on the three bulletin boards with thumbtacks throughout the athletic club. Rather than risk the health of the athletes, they thoroughly checked the thousands of thermometers to insure their worthiness; otherwise they needed to be thrown away.

â€œTHâ€ Exceptions

Thomas
Thompson
Theresa
Thailand
Thames
Esther
Thyme

Voicing the â€˜Tâ€™ Sound

If a â€˜Tâ€™ falls within two voiced sounds (usually vowels), the â€˜Tâ€™ becomes voiced like a â€˜Dâ€™.
Examples:

Water Â» Wader (the whole word is voiced)
Better Â» Bedder
Butter Â» Budder

Voiced â€˜Tâ€™ Practice

Betty bought a bit of better butter.
But, said she,
This butterâ€™s bitter.
If I put it in my batter,
Itâ€™ll make my batter bitter.

4.F&V &SH&ZSH

F&V

Practice Words with â€˜Fâ€™

Foot
Find
Finally
Family
Freedom

Telephone
Symphony

Practice Sentences

Do you feel like a physical wreck? Are you fed up with your feeling of fatigue? Have you had enough of feeling rough? Why donâ€™t you fight fever with Pharaohâ€™s Friend. A medicine that is tough on Flu.

Practice Words with â€˜Vâ€™

Vote
Vine
Oven
Evaluate
Voice
Travel
River
Every
Glove
Alive
Leave

Comparing â€˜Fâ€™ and â€˜Vâ€™

Feel â€“ Veal
Safe â€“ Save
Fat â€“ Vat
Fine â€“ Vine
Face â€“ Vase
Fan â€“ Van
Foul â€“ Vowel
Proof â€“ Prove

Practice Phrases

A famous athlete
A food vendor
The Foreign Service
Summer vacation
Vocabulary test
Over the rainbow
Our first victory
Harvard University
Husband and wife
Very well done

Practice Sentences

-Her promotion in the firm was well deserved.
-There was only one survivor on the island.
-Steve noticed that the olive juice must have stained his sleeve.
-The street vendor was selling souvenirs to tourists.
-Dave gave me his car so that I could drive on New Yearâ€™s Eve.
-There were several dents in the rear fender.
-Tom placed several tomatoes from the vine into a basket.

SH

â€˜SHâ€™ practice words

Beginning

She
Sugar
Sure
Shadow
Sheep
Shirt
Shoe
Shape
Chicago
Chef

Middle

Nation
Motion
Mission
Special
Reputation
Official
Machine
Fishing
Insurance
Sunshine
Ocean
Tissue
Addition
Subtraction

End

Rush
Dish
Establish
Splash
Irish
Fresh
Finish

â€˜SHâ€™ Sentences

-The fishing trip was planned and we left to go to the ocean.
-Was the chef ashamed to use the precious sugar?
-Sharon gave a special performance.
-He will be stationed in Washington, D.C, the nationâ€™s capital.
-She went to a fashion show after taking a shower.
-She sells seashells by the seashore.
-The social club was praised for their cooperation.

â€˜SHâ€™ Practice

Joeâ€™s weather machine shows a sharp drop in air pressure, especially offshore. Ships in motion on the ocean should be sure to use caution.

â€˜ZSHâ€™

practice words

Middle

Usual
Unusual
Usually
Vision
Visual
Conclusion
Asia
Version
Division
Casual
Television

End

Massage
Prestige

Practice Sentences

-Itâ€™s not unusual for people to study division in Asia.
-I usually use a measuring cup to measure erosion.
-The beige walls were the usual color in the treasury building.

5.L

â€˜Lâ€™ at the beginning of words

Lunch
Local
London
Learn
Large
Life
Lobby
Library
Lucky
Lift
Laugh
Long

â€˜Lâ€™ in the middle of words

Inflation
Believe
Volume
Glue
Elevator

Pulling

Alive
Color

â€˜Lâ€™ at the end of a word

â€¢ To produce an â€˜Lâ€™ at the end of a word, remember to slowly raise your tongue upward, towards your upper teeth, while keeping your bottom jaw as open as possible. The â€˜Lâ€™ sound comes from the tongue movement, not from the placement.
(Using your finger to push down on your bottom teeth to keep your jaw open, may be helpful for practicing.)

Practice words

Will
Ball
Tall
Call
Small
Control
Bowl
Apple
Miracle
Powerful
Control
Financial
People

â€˜Lâ€™ Sentences

-The lollipop fell into the cool water.
-Her driverâ€™s license was pulled out of the blue golf bag.
-Blakeâ€™s bowling ball fell under his tools.
-Carl could not locate the lemons or the limes.
-The school was a mile away from the hill.
-The golf club was made of steel.
-Alâ€™s goal was to play baseball with Carol.
-A certified letter was delivered for the enrollment list.
-It was revealing to look at the smiling lawyer.

â€˜FLâ€™ Blend Poem

A flea and a fly, flew up in a flue.
Said the flea, â€œLet us fly!â€
Said the fly, â€œLet us flee!â€
So they flew through a flaw in the flue.

Practice using â€˜Willâ€™

6.ed

Three rules for â€˜â€“ED â€™ endings

Rule 1
If a word ends in an unvoiced consonant, when adding â€˜-edâ€™, just add an Unvoiced â€˜Tâ€™
Rule 2
If a word ends in a voiced consonant, add a Voiced â€˜Dâ€™
Rule 3
If a word ends in a â€˜Tâ€™ or a â€˜Dâ€™ sound, we add a Voiced â€˜EDâ€™

Bob raked the leaves and then started to wash his car. He then loaded up the dishwasher and finished washing his dishes.
Susan spilled her drink on the spotted rug. She cleaned it up with a napkin, which wasted a lot of time.
He thanked me and offered me money, if I picked up the used equipment.

Consonant â€˜Hâ€™
When an â€˜Hâ€™ is at the beginning of a word it is pronounced with a strong, loud air-stream.

8.Vowels, â€˜EEâ€™& â€˜Iâ€™

Front Vowels: (From high to low)

EE - as in Heat
I - as in Hit

â€˜Areâ€™ vs. â€˜Ourâ€™

Then close your mouth and say â€œWereâ€.
Think of the word â€˜Ourâ€™ as having two syllables.
Pronounced as â€¦â€œAU-WEREâ€

13.Phrase Reductions And Intonation

Phrase Reductions

(Going to try) becomes â€˜gunna tryâ€™

Iâ€™m gunna try to finish this book.

(Want to eat) becomes â€˜wanna eatâ€™

(Got to leave) becomes â€˜gotta leaveâ€™

(Ought to believe) becomes â€˜oughta believeâ€™

(Out of bed) becomes â€˜outa bedâ€™

(Did you go?) becomes â€˜Didja goâ€™

(Wonâ€™t you play?) becomes â€˜Woncha playâ€™

(Didnâ€™t you know?) becomes â€˜Didincha knowâ€™

(Is he?) becomes â€˜Izzyâ€™

(What do you want?) becomes â€˜Whadaya_wantâ€™

Intonation Practice

Have you ever tried one of Dianeâ€™s Donuts? They are so delicious. I have eaten many different kinds of donuts, from all over the country; however, I have never tasted anything, quite like Donuts made by Diane. I have been told that she uses the finest and freshest ingredients that money can buy. The best flour, the best eggs and the best milk. I am sure, that once you taste these incredible donuts, you will run and tell all of your friends.

14.Putting it all together â€“ Part I and The 10 Key steps towards Improvement

Putting it all together â€“ Part I

lueâ€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦..

10 keys

Number 1. Practice and listen.
Number 2. Do not leave off the endings of words.
Number 3. Make a list of frequently used words.
Number 4. Open your mouth more when you speak English.
Number 5. Donâ€™t be afraid to speak.
Number 6. Read aloud in English for ten to 15 minutes every day.
Number 7. Record your own voice and listen for pronunciation errors.
Number 8. Watch the mouth movements of native speakers and imitate them.
Number 9. Buy books on tape. Read along with the tape - out loud.
Number 10. Be patient.
